questions.question: Original DNA sequence: 5'-ATG GCA TCG GAA UAC-3'. Mutated sequence: 5'-ATG GCA TCG GAA UAA-3'. Identify the mutation.
questions.explanation: and destroying the functional activity. This is called Nonsense mutation. Based on the Effects on Amino acid sequence Silent Mutation (Option C ruled out) Missense Mutation (Option D ruled out) Nonsense Mutation (Option B) Mutation may change the codon for one amino acid to a synonym for the same amino acid. It has no effect on the phenotype. Degeneracy of the code. Different amino acid is incorporated due to change in the nucleotide sequence. It can be acceptable, partially acceptable, and unacceptable . Codon for an amino acid is mutated to a termination codon (UAA or UAG) causing premature termination of translation. Frameshift mutation (Option A) is the deletion or insertion of nucleotides leading to altered reading of frame in the mRNA. Reference: Harper Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page 407, 408

questions.question: Identify the type of mutation illustrated in the following DNA sequences? Starting sequence: Mutated sequence:
questions.explanation: nucleotide is substituted by the other), which is a point mutation. A mutation is defined as a change in nucleotide sequence of DNA. Based on the Effects on Nucleotide sequence Point mutation (Option A) Frameshift mutation (Option B ruled out) Substitution of one nucleotide by another. Transition : Purine is replaced by a purine and a pyrimidine is replaced by a pyrimidine. Transversion : Purine is replaced by a pyrimidine and vice versa. Deletion (Option C ruled out) or insertion (Option D ruled out) of nucleotides leading to altered reading frame in the mRNA.

questions.question: Which technique is commonly used for DNA sequencing to identify mutations by determining the precise order of nucleotides in a DNA sample?
questions.explanation: synthesis, allowing the sequence of DNA to be read by analyzing fragment lengths. There are cytogenetics and molecular methods for detection of mutations. Methods Uses Advantages/ disadvantages Cytogenetics Karyotype Detecting numerical and gross structural aberrations Low-resolution Time consuming FISH (Fluorescence in situ hybridization) (Option A ruled out) Detects copy number variations, structural alterations like translocations and microdeletion Detects Limitation: Can be used only for known defects CGH (Comparative genomic hybridization) Detects copy number variations of genetic material Can be used to detect unknown chromosomal aberrations Used only for losses and gains Molecular RFLP (Restriction fragment length polymorphism) Restriction fragments are separated by electrophoresis Requires availability of enzyme with restriction site at the mutation site DNA Sequencing Sanger technique (Option C) is the most widely used. Directly determines the nucleotide sequence of a DNA fragment. Detects point mutations, small deletions and insertions. DNA microarray Microscopic DNA spots attached to a solid surface Multiple mutations can be detected. ARMS PCR ( Amplification refractory mutation system) Allele-specific amplification of mutant and normal allele, determination of the genotype of an individual Highly sensitive May increase time and costs Multiplex PCR (Polymerase chain reaction) Amplification of more than one target simultaneously Reduces time and labour requirements Lower sensitivity and specificity Real-time PCR Amplification, detection, and quantification of target Increased specificity Eliminates post-amplification analyses More expensive MLPA (Multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification) (Option B ruled out) Deletions and duplications Identifies very small single gene aberrations (50-70 nt) DGGE (Denaturing Gradient Gel Electrophoresis) Based on migration within gradient gel electrophoresis Detects close to 100% of point mutations SSCP (Single Strand Conformational Polymorphism) (Option D ruled out) Based on migration of single-stranded conformation on gel electrophoresis Detects about 80–90% of point mutations Hetero-duplex analysis Based on homoduplices and heteroduplices motilities in gel electrophoresis Detects nearly 80% of mutations OLA (Oligonucleotide ligation assay) It is based on the ligation of two flanked primers annealed with target sequences Detects all base exchanges PTT (Protein truncation test) It is based on a combination of PCR, transcription, and translation Detects translation-terminating mutations. Missense mutations are not detected. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3883366/ Table 5 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3883366/

questions.question: Which class of antibiotics inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by blocking the attachment of aminoacyl-tRNA to the ribosomal A site?
questions.explanation: aminoacyl tRNA to the A site. Inhibitors of Protein Synthesis Mechanism of action Reversible Inhibitors in Bacteria (bacteriostatic) Tetracyclines (Option A) Binds to the 30S ribosome of bacteria and inhibit attachment of aminoacyl tRNA to the A site. Chloramphenicol (Option B ruled out) Inhibits the peptidyl transferase activity of bacterial ribosomes Erythromycin (macrolides) (Option C ruled out) and clindamycin Inhibits the translocation process. Irreversible Inhibitors in Bacteria (bactericidal) Aminoglycoside Bind to 30S subunit of bacterial ribosomes. Misreading of mRNA. Inhibit the initiation complex formation and totally inhibit protein synthesis. Inhibitors of Protein Synthesis in Mammals Puromycin (Option D ruled out) Analogue of tyrosine tRNA and attaches to the “A” site of the ribosome causing premature termination. Cycloheximide Inhibits peptidyl transferase in 60S subunit Diphtheria toxin Inactivation of EF-2 by attachment of ADP to EF-2 Reference: Vasudevan 7e, pg 605

questions.question: What is the total number of ATPs required for activating amino acids by aminoacyl tRNA synthetase?
questions.explanation: by aminoacyl tRNA synthetase (Option B) 2 Activating of eEF1 (A attaches amino acyl tRNA to A site) 1 Activating eEF2 (helps in translocation of ribosomes) 1 Total 4 Reference: Vasudevan 7e, pg 602

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about aminoacyl tRNA?

options.A: Attaches to the A site of 60s ribosomes

questions.explanation: translation. Involved in the elongation step of translation. Guided by eIF2C (Option C ruled out) Guided by eEF1A Attaches to the P site of 60s ribosome Attaches to the A site of 60s ribosome (Option A) Utilises 3 high energy phosphates for each peptide bond formation (Option B ruled out) Utilises 4 high energy phosphates for each peptide bond formation Reference: Harper 32e, pg 410, 413 Vasudevan 7e, pg 602

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT TRUE regarding the initiation of translation?

options.A: eIF3 and 1A stabilize 60s ribosomal subunit to prevent reassociation with 40s.
options.B: Methionine tRNA scans mRNA to identify the initiation AUG codon
options.C: ATP dependent helicase eIF4A/4B breaks hydrogen bonds to remove the hairpin loops
options.D: Association of mRNA with the 43S preinitiation complex forms the 48S initiation complex

questions.explanation: Steps of initiation: It involves tRNA, rRNA, mRNA, eukaryotic initiation factors (eIFs), GTP, ATP, and amino acids. 1. Ribosomal Dissociation: 80S ribosomes dissociate into 40S and 60S subunits. eIF3 and 1A stabilize 40s ribosomal subunit to prevent reassociation with 60s, allowing other translation initiation factors to associate with the 40S subunit. (Option A) 2. Formation of the 43S Preinitiation Complex: Binary complex is formed by binding of GTP and eIF-2. This binary complex then binds to methionyl tRNA. The GTP-eIF-2-tRNAi ternary complex binds to the 40S ribosomal subunit to form the 43S preinitiation complex. 3. Formation of the 48S Initiation Complex: The 5 ′ termini of mRNA molecules in eukaryotic cells are “capped.” The binding of mRNA to the 43S preinitiation complex is facilitated by 7meG-cap. 4G/4A attaches to the cap through 4E, which forms 4F. ATP-dependent helicase eIF4A/4B breaks hydrogen bonds to remove the hairpin loops and make mRNA single-stranded. (Option C ruled out) Methionine tRNA scans the mRNA to identify the initiation AUG codon, and attach the tRNA to AUG at the P site. (Option B ruled out) The association of mRNA with the 43S preinitiation complex forms the 48S initiation complex. (Option D ruled out) 4. Formation of the 80S Initiation Complex: The 60S ribosomal subunit binds to the 48S initiation complex by hydrolysis of the GTP bound to eIF-2 by eIF-5. This results in the release of the initiation factors bound to the 48S initiation complex. The rapid association of the 40S and 60S subunits forms the 80S ribosome. At this point, the met-tRNAi is on the P site of the ribosome, ready for the elongation cycle to commence

questions.question: Match the following phases of translation (Column A) with the events involved (Column B). Column A Column B 1. Elongation a. RF1 binds with RF3 and GTP 2. Initiation b. Binding of aminoacyl-tRNA to the ribosome's A site 3. Termination c. Methionine tRNA scans mRNA for AUG codon
questions.explanation: stabilized by various initiation factors. Formation of the 43S Preinitiation Complex: The 40S ribosomal subunit, in association with initiation factors, binds to the initiator tRNA (carrying methionine in eukaryotes or formyl-methionine in prokaryotes)forming the 43S preinitiation complex. Formation of 48S initiation complex: The 43S complex binds to the 5' end of the mRNA, and scans for start codon which upon recognition, the 48S initiation complex is formed. Formation of the 80S Initiation Complex: Binding of the 60S ribosomal subunit to the 48S initiation. The met-tRNA on the P site of the ribosome is ready for the elongation cycle. Elongation Binding of Aminoacyl-tRNA to the A Site Peptide Bond Formation Elongation factor 2 (EF2) binds to and displaces the peptidyl tRNA from the A site to the P site Termination Ribosome reaches the terminator codon sequence (UAA, UAG or UGA) Releasing factor(RF1), (RF3) and GTP complex promotes hydrolysis releasing the protein and the tRNA from the P site. Reference: Harper Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page 410-414

questions.question: Sickle cell anaemia is suspected in a 25-year-old patient who presents with episodes of abdominal pain and fatigue. Genetic analysis reveals GAG in the 6th position is replaced with GTG. Which type of mutation here results in haemoglobin that is still functional but altered?
questions.explanation: acid) is replaced by the GTG codon (which codes for valine) at the 6th position of the hemoglobin gene resulting in the production of hemoglobin S (HbS) instead of the normal hemoglobin A (HbA). This partially acceptable mutation still allows the hemoglobin to carry oxygen, but with altered efficiency ( accumulation of globin chains and causes sickling crisis on exposure to deoxygenation.), leading to symptoms of sickle cell anemia. Sickle cell anemia is an example of point mutation, transversion, missense and partially acceptable mutation. Effects on the functioning of the protein: Based on the Effects on the function of protein Acceptable mutation: (Option C ruled out) Partially acceptable mutation: (Option B) Unacceptable mutation: (Option A ruled out) Change in the nucleotide sequence causes alteration in the amino sequence that does not affect the functioning of the protein. Example: Hb Sydney Change in the nucleotide sequence causing alteration in the amino sequence that affects the functioning of the protein but it is not immediately life-threatening. Example: HbS - GAG is replaced by GTG which replaces the glutamic acid to valine. Change in the nucleotide sequence causes alteration in the amino sequence that affects the functioning of the protein so extensively that it is immediately life-threatening. Example: Congenital methemoglobinemia (HbM) - Histidine (CAU) is replaced with tyrosine (UAU) in alpha-chain. Nonsense mutation (Option D) : Codon for an amino acid is mutated to a termination codon (UAA or UAG) causing premature termination of translation. Reference: Vasudevan 7e, pg 613 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7510211/

questions.question: A DNA sequence originally reads 5'-ATG GCA TCG TAC-3'. After a mutation, it reads 5'-ATG GCT CGT AC-3'. Identify the mutation that has occured?
questions.explanation: reading frame. This is a frameshift mutation. A mutation is defined as a change in the nucleotide sequence of DNA. Based on the Effects on Nucleotide sequence Point mutation (Option B ruled out) Frameshift mutation (Option A) Substitution of one nucleotide by another. Transition (Option C ruled out) : A purine is replaced by a purine, and a pyrimidine is replaced by a pyrimidine. Transversion : Purine is replaced by a pyrimidine and vice versa. Deletion (Option A ruled out) or insertion (Option D ruled out) of nucleotides leads to an altered reading frame in the mRNA. Reference: Harper Biochemistry, 3nd Edition, Page 407-409

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately reflects a difference between DNA and RNA, considering their roles in genetic information processing and stability?

options.A: RNA's 2'-hydroxyl group enhances its stability compared to DNA.
options.B: RNA polymerases need a primer; DNA polymerases do not.
options.C: RNA forms complex structures; DNA remains a double helix
options.D: DNA degrades more rapidly than RNA due to the presence of a 2'-hydroxyl group.

questions.explanation: to intrachain base pairing (A-U, G-C). DNA is typically double-stranded with a stable double-helix structure. Aspect DNA RNA Sugar Deoxyribose (lacks 2' hydroxyl group) (Option D ruled out) Ribose (has 2' hydroxyl group) Bases Adenine (A), Guanine (G), Cytosine (C), Thymine (T) Adenine (A), Guanine (G), Cytosine (C), Uracil (U) Structure Double-stranded helix, antiparallel strands, complementary base pairing (A-T, G-C) DNA follows both Chargaff rule of base pairing and Watson and Crick base pairing rule. Single-stranded, can fold into complex structures with intrachain base pairing (A-U, G-C) (Option C) Do not follow Chargaff's Rule of Base Pairing. Watson and Crick Base pairing rule is followed here. Function Stores genetic information Various roles in gene expression: Messenger RNA (mRNA) - Carries genetic information from DNA to ribosomes for protein synthesis Ribosomal RNA (rRNA) - Major component of ribosomes, involved in protein synthesis Transfer RNA (tRNA) - Transports amino acids to ribosomes during protein synthesis Stability More stable due to lack of 2'-hydroxyl group B (Option A ruled out) Less stable, more susceptible to hydrolysis Degradation Susceptibility Less prone to degradation, stable over generations More prone to degradation, shorter lifespan, important for regulating gene expression Synthesis Primer Requirement Requires RNA primer for initiation (Option B ruled out) Can initiate synthesis de novo, no primer needed Proofreading and Fidelity High fidelity with 3' to 5' exonuclease activity for proofreading Higher error rate but can backtrack and cleave incorrect nucleotides. Reference: Harper’s Biochemistry Page 335,352- 357

questions.question: Which of the following statements are true regarding codons? A, G, T, C are RNA nucleotides A, G, T, C are DNA nucleotides A, G, U, C are RNA nucleotides A, G, U, C are DNA nucleotides
questions.explanation: codons. Aspect Details Codon Three-nucleotide sequence in mRNA Codon Functions Specifies an amino acid sequence in proteins. Start codon (AUG): Signals the initiation of protein synthesis. Stop codons(UAA, UAG, and UGA) : Signals termination of protein synthesis Total Codons 64 (4 nucleotides, each position can be A, U, G, or C) DNA Nucleotides A, G, T, C (Options A, C, D ruled out) RNA Nucleotides A, G, U (replaces T), C (Options A, C, D ruled out) Amino Acid Codons 61 codons encode 20 amino acids Reading Frame mRNA sequence read from start codon to stop codon (Open Reading Frame) Reference: Harper 32e, Pg 404, 405, 414, 420

questions.question: The wobble phenomenon in tRNA decoding is primarily due to:

options.A: Inosine forming non-standard base pairs at the third codon position.
options.B: The exact matching of all three nucleotides between codon and anticodon.
options.C: Single tRNA binds only to one specific codon.
options.D: The rigid Watson-Crick base pairing at the third position of the codon.

questions.explanation: A) at the third position of the codon, allowing a single tRNA to recognize multiple codons. Wobble Phenomenon Definition : Flexible base-pairing between the third nucleotide of a codon (mRNA) and the corresponding nucleotide of the tRNA anticodon. (Option B ruled out) Function : Allows one tRNA molecule to bind to multiple codons coding for the same amino acid. (Option C ruled out) Inosine (I): A modified nucleotide in some tRNA anticodons, pairs with U, C, and A. Non-standard pairing is more flexible than Watson-Crick base pairing, which is strict for the first two codon nucleotides. Codon Position Standard Base Pairing Wobble Pairing Example 1st and 2nd Watson-Crick rules (Option D ruled out) Strict AG A and AG G code for Arginine. 3rd Non-standard pairing Flexible AGA/AGG with UCU, GGU/GGC/GGA with CCI Reference: Harper 32e, Pg 407

questions.question: In the context of genetic code degeneracy, which of the following accurately describes its impact on protein synthesis?

options.A: Single codon specifies one amino acid.
options.B: Multiple codons can code for the same amino acid.
options.C: Flexibility occurs at the 2nd codon position.
options.D: Inosine in mRNA contributes to the flexibility in pairing.

questions.explanation: rules. Degeneracy in the Genetic Code : Multiple codons can encode the same amino acid. (Option A ruled out) (Option B) There are 64 possible codons but only 20 amino acids. Example: Six codons (UCU, UCC, UCA, UCG, AGU, AGC) all code for serine. Causes of Degeneracy : Wobble Hypothesis : Flexibility in base-pairing rules between the third nucleotide of mRNA codon and the tRNA anticodon . (Option C ruled out) Inosine (I) Role : Inosine in t RNA anticodons can pair with U, C, and A, enhancing code flexibility. (Option D ruled out) Reference: Harper 32e, Pg 405, 407.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the primary mechanisms and applications of RNA interference (RNAi)?

options.A: Degradation of mRNA; used for gene manipulation and therapy.
options.B: Enhancement of mRNA synthesis; used for genetic modifications.
options.C: Conversion of mRNA to DNA; used for protein structure studies.
options.D: Stabilisation of mRNA; used for treating infections.

questions.explanation: manipulation and therapy applications. RNA Interference (RNAi) Definition : Biological process where double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) silences specific gene expressions. Mechanisms : Degradation of messenger RNA (mRNA) molecules corresponding to the target gene. Reduction of expression levels of the target gene. Applications : Tool in genetic research and biotechnology for gene knockdown. Understanding gene function. Developing therapeutic strategies. Enhancement of mRNA synthesis; used for genetic modifications (Option B) does not enhance mRNA synthesis; it silences gene expression. Conversion of mRNA to DNA; used for protein structure studies (Option C) does not involve converting mRNA to DNA; it targets mRNA for degradation Stabilisation of mRNA; used for treating infections (Option D) causes degradation of mRNA, not stabilisation. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1686061/pdf/ajhg00189-0080.pdf https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8538544/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC309050/

questions.question: A 25-year-old student is reviewing the roles of small RNAs in cellular processes. She learns about small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs) and small interfering RNAs (siRNAs). Which of the following statements about snRNAs and/or siRNAs is true?

options.A: Both snRNAs and siRNAs are involved in the degradation of mRNA.
options.B: snRNAs form complexes with the RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC).
options.C: snRNAs are primarily involved in mRNA splicing and are located in the nucleus.
options.D: snRNAs are typically found in the cytoplasm, while siRNAs are found in the nucleus.

questions.explanation: for removing introns from pre-mRNA (hnRNA) during splicing, which occurs in the nucleus. Feature snRNAs siRNAs Main Function RNA processing Gene regulation Location (Option C) (Option D ruled out) Nucleus Cytoplasm Involvement (Option A ruled out) mRNA splicing, transcription elongation mRNA degradation Specific Types U1, U2, U4, U5, U6 (splicing); U7 (histone mRNAs); 7SK (transcription) Typically 21-25 nucleotides long Role in mRNA Removes introns, generates correct 3' ends of histone mRNAs Silences gene expression Source Endogenous snRNAs Endogenous/exogenous dsRNAs processed into siRNAs Processing Mechanism Forms complexes with proteins (snRNPs) for splicing Processed by Dicer enzyme into siRNA duplexes Associated Complex (Option B ruled out) Small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNPs) RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC) Length Varies; generally 100-300 nucleotides 21-25 nucleotides Stability Generally stable, involved in essential RNA processes Short-lived, rapidly degrades target mRNA Biogenesis Transcribed by RNA polymerase II or III Derived from longer dsRNA precursors Function in Disease Defects can lead to splicing disorders (e.g., spinal muscular atrophy) Utilized in RNAi therapies for gene silencing (e.g., in cancer) Example Applications Studying splicing mechanisms, understanding transcription regulation Therapeutic gene silencing, functional genomics studies Reference: Harper 32e, Pg 356, 357, 358, 359, 402.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the synthesis of mRNA?

options.A: Introns are the coding sequence in a mRNA
options.B: 7-methyl guanosine gets added to the 3’ end of mRNA
options.C: Process of splicing occurs in the cytoplasm
options.D: Heteronuclear RNA is not a functional mRNA

questions.explanation: the precursor to mRNA , containing introns and exons. It undergoes processing like splicing, capping, and polyadenylation to become functional mRNA. Synthesis of mRNA: Introns are the coding sequence in a mRNA (Option A): Exons are the coding sequences, while introns are the non-coding sequences in a mRNA. 7-methyl guanosine gets added to the 3’ end of mRNA (Option B): 7-methyl guanosine gets added to the 5’ end of mRNA, while Poly-A tail gets added to the 3’ end of mRNA. Process of splicing occurs in the cytoplasm (Option C): Process of splicing occurs in the nucleus.

questions.question: Which of the following steps in the process of tRNA synthesis occurs in the cytoplasm?

options.A: Rearrangement of glycosidic linkages giving rise to pseudouridine
options.C: Fourth post-transcriptional modification of random methylation
options.D: Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases attach the amino acid

questions.explanation: acid to the tRNA, making it functional in the cytoplasm. Synthesis of tRNA: Rearrangement of glycosidic linkages giving rise to pseudouridine (Option A) is incorrect because pseudouridine formation occurs in the nucleus , as part of post-transcriptional modifications of tRNA. Deamination creating inosine (Option B) is incorrect because inosine is formed in the nucleus by the deamination of adenosine during tRNA maturation. Inosine is important for wobble base pairing in codon recognition. Fourth post-transcriptional modification of random methylation (Option C) is incorrect because methylation of tRNA (as part of modifications like methylation of ribose or bases) occurs in the nucleus , not the cytoplasm.

questions.question: Which statement best describes the wobble hypothesis in relation to tRNA's function?

options.A: Allows multiple tRNAs to bind to a single codon.
options.B: Explains tRNA's ability to bind to any codon with perfect complementarity.
options.C: Single tRNA recognizes multiple codons due to flexible base pairing.
options.D: Accounts for varying tRNA lengths matching different mRNA sequences.

questions.explanation: base pairing at the third position of the codon. tRNA / transfer RNA: Component Description Function Amino Acid Acceptor Arm Located at the 3' end, ending in CCA, which is added post-transcriptionally. The amino acid is attached to the 3 ′ -OH group of the A moiety. Charging : Amino acids are attached to the tRNA by aminoacyl-tRNA synthetases for protein synthesis. D Arm Contains dihydrouridine, a modified base. Contributes to the overall structure and recognition of tRNA by its corresponding aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase. Recognition : Ensures correct aminoacylation by interacting with aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase. T ψ C Arm Named for its ribothymidine (T), pseudouridine ( ψ ), and cytidine (C) content. Involved in binding tRNA to the ribosome. Binding : Positions tRNA correctly at the ribosome for protein synthesis. Anticodon Loop Opposite the amino acid acceptor arm, contains a sequence of three nucleotides (anticodon) complementary to the codon on mRNA. Wobble phenomenon Third nucleotide pair formation is non-specific (more than one codon coding for a single amino acid) (Or) Reduced stringency when the third nucleotide pair is formed between codon and anti-codon. (Or) When tRNA is written in 5’, 3’ direction, the first nucleotide of the anticodon of tRNA is not specific Degeneracy More than one codon coding for a single amino acid because of the wobble phenomenon. Codon Recognition : Ensures the correct amino acid is added to the polypeptide chain during translation. Variable Arm Located between the T ψ C arm and the anticodon loop. Its length varies among different tRNA species and contributes to the tertiary structure of tRNA. Structural Flexibility : Aids in interactions with the ribosome and other translation factors. Allows multiple tRNAs to bind to a single codon (Option A): The wobble hypothesis focuses on how a single tRNA can recognize and bind to several codons that code for the same amino acid, not how multiple tRNAs interact with one codon. Explains tRNA's ability to bind to any codon with perfect complementarity (Option B): The wobble hypothesis involves flexible or non-standard base pairing. It does not imply that tRNAs bind with perfect complementarity to all codons. Accounts for varying tRNA lengths matching different mRNA sequences (Option D): The hypothesis does not address differences in tRNA lengths or their relationship with mRNA sequences.

questions.question: Which of the following types of rRNA is associated with the 40S ribosomal subunit in eukaryotic cells?
questions.explanation: IIIII In eukaryotic cells, the ribosome is composed of two subunits: the small 40S subunit and the large 60S subunit. The 40S subunit contains the 18S rRNA, which is essential for the structural integrity and function of the ribosome during protein synthesis. The 60S subunit, on the other hand, includes the 5S, 5.8S, and 28S rRNAs (Options A and C ruled out) The 16S rRNA is found in the small subunit of prokaryotic ribosomes, not in eukaryotic ribosomes (Option D ruled out) Type of RNA Characteristics Function mRNA (messenger RNA) Single-stranded Varies in length depending on the encoded protein Contains exons and introns (in eukaryotes) Carries genetic information from DNA to the ribosome Encodes the amino acid sequence of proteins Undergoes processing such as capping, polyadenylation, and splicing in eukaryotes tRNA (transfer RNA) Small, typically 73-93 nucleotides Cloverleaf structure Contains an anticodon and an amino acid attachment site Transfers specific amino acids to the ribosome during protein synthesis Recognizes codons on mRNA through its anticodon region Plays a critical role in translating the genetic code into protein rRNA (ribosomal RNA) Forms the core of ribosome's structure Eukaryotic ribosomes: 18S (40S subunit), 5.8S, 28S, 5S (components of the 60S subunit) Prokaryotic ribosomes: 16S, 23S, 5S Major structural and functional components of ribosomes Catalyzes peptide bond formation during protein synthesis snRNA (small nuclear RNA) Small, usually less than 200 nucleotides Found in the nucleus Component of the spliceosome Involved in the processing of pre-mRNA in eukaryotes Essential for splicing introns from pre-mRNA miRNA (microRNA) Small, approximately 22 nucleotides Single-stranded Forms hairpin structures Regulates gene expression post-transcriptionally Binds to complementary sequences on target mRNAs, resulting in translational repression or mRNA degradation Plays a role in various biological processes including development, differentiation, and apoptosis siRNA (small interfering RNA) Short, double-stranded RNA, about 20-25 nucleotides Originates from longer double-stranded RNA Involved in the RNA interference (RNAi) pathway Mediates the degradation of specific mRNAs Used experimentally to silence gene expression
